@graph.definition: The first official national Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD), proclaimed in the Australian Commonwealth Gazette No. 84 of 6 October 1966. Area of use: Australia onshore and offshore, and Papua New Guinea onshore.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 49: Australia – onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 108°E and 114°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 50: onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 114°E and 120°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 52: Australia – onshore and offshore between 120°E and 126°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD66, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG66 zone 52: Australia – onshore and offshore between 126°E and 132°E.

An update to the official Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD), adopted and in effect from 1984. The AGD84 national system replaced AGD66 but was officially adopted only in Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia; it was later replaced by GDA94. Area of use: Australia – Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia, federal areas offshore west of 129°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 49: Australia – onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 108°E and 114°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 50: onshore and offshore to 200 nautical mile EEZ (Exclusive Economic Zone) boundary between 114°E and 120°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a Transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 51: Australia – onshore and offshore between 120°E and 126°E.

The accompanying national map projection to AGD84, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for AMG84 zone 52: Western Australia east of 126°E, South Australia west of 132°E, offshore federal waters between 126°E and 129°E.

The Australian national map projection accompanying AGD66. The Australian Map Grid (AMG) is derived from a transverse Mercator projection of latitudes and longitudes on the Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD66). The AMG corresponds with the Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid, with a system of rectangular grid coordinates (eastings and northings) expressed in metres. AMG zones are numbered from zone 47 (with central meridian 99°E) to zone 58 (with central meridian 165°E). Each zone is 6° wide with a half degree of overlapping.

The Australian national map projection accompanying AGD84. The Australian Map Grid (AMG) is derived from a transverse Mercator projection of latitudes and longitudes on the Australian Geodetic Datum (AGD84). The AMG corresponds with the Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid, with a system of rectangular grid coordinates (eastings and northings) expressed in metres. AMG zones are numbered from zone 47 (with central meridian 99°E) to zone 58 (with central meridian 165°E). Each zone is 6° wide with a half degree of overlapping.

Between 1858 and 1966, geodetic surveys in Australia were computed on either a jurisdiction (state or territory) or regional basis using more than four different spheroids and as many as twenty coordinate origins. In Western Australia, the most widely used geodatum and ellipsoid since 1945 was the Clarke 1858; the State was covered by four separate longitudinal zones, numbered 1 (one) to 4 (four), each with a 5° longitude width.
Zone 1 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 113.5°E to 118.5°E.
Zone 2 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 118.5°E to 123.5°E.
Zone 3 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 123.5°E to 128.5°E.
Zone 4 of the Clarke 1858 geodatum, extending from longitudes 128.5°E to 133.5°E.

The official geodetic datum adopted nationally in June 2020. GDA2020 is a coordinate reference system with an origin that coincides with a determination of the centre of mass of the earth, hence the term geocentric. GDA2020 is a plate-fixed or static coordinate datum based on the International Terrestrial Reference Frame 1992 (ITRF92), held at the reference epoch of 1 January 2020. Area of use is the same as GDA94, i.e. all the areas contained within Australia’s marine jurisdiction (within 200 nautical miles of Australia) and its external territories, and the areas of Australia’s continental shelf beyond 200 nautical miles as confirmed by the United Nations Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf: Australia including Lord Howe Island, Macquarie Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island; all onshore and offshore.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 49: Australia – onshore and offshore west of 114°E; Christmas Island – offshore east of 108°E.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 50: Australia – onshore and offshore between 114°E and 120°E.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 51: Australia – onshore and offshore between 120°E and 126°E.

The accompanying national map projection to GDA2020, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA2020 zone 52: Australia – onshore and offshore between 126°E and 132°E.

The official geodetic datum adopted nationally in January 2000. GDA94 replaced the Australian Geodetic Datum 1966 (AGD66) and Australian Geodetic Datum 1984 (AGD84), and was later replaced by GDA2020. GDA94 is a coordinate reference system whose origin coincides with a determination of the centre of mass of the earth, hence the term geocentric. GDA94 is a plate-fixed or static coordinate datum based on the International Terrestrial Reference Frame 1992 (ITRF92), held at the reference epoch of 1 January 1994. The distance between the origin points of GDA94 and AGD is approximately 200 metres. Area of use: Australia including Lord Howe Island, Macquarie Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island; all onshore and offshore.

The accompanying national map projection to MGA94, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 49 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA94 zone 49: Australia - onshore and offshore west of 114° E; Christmas Island - offshore east of 108°E.

The accompanying national map projection to MGA94, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 50 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA94 zone 50: Australia – onshore and offshore between 114°E and 120°E.

The accompanying national map projection to MGA94, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 51 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA94 zone 51: Australia – onshore and offshore between 120°E and 126°E.

The accompanying national map projection to MGA94, a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to zone 52 of the internationally accepted Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. Area of use for MGA94 zone 52: Australia – onshore and offshore between 126°E and 132°E.

A local grid is a locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary, fixed point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted, instead of using a national or global datum.

Locally defined coordinate reference systems, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted. The coordinates of the base station point are known.

Locally defined coordinate reference system, typically used during mineral exploration. Local grids measure positions relative to an arbitrary point (usually a GPS base station) on the site/area where the activity is conducted. The coordinates of the base station point are not known.

The standard map projection associated with GDA2020 is the Map Grid of Australia 2020 (MGA2020), a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to the internationally standardized Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. The UTM system has been used with the GRS80 ellipsoid and Geocentric Datum of Australia (GDA2020) latitudes and longitudes to define MGA2020.

The standard map projection associated with GDA94 is the Map Grid of Australia 1994 (MGA94), a transverse Mercator projection that conforms to the internationally standardized Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) grid system. At that time the recommended reference ellipsoid was also changed from ANS to the Geodetic Reference System 1980 (GRS80) ellipsoid. Area of use: Australia including Lord Howe Island, Macquarie Island, Ashmore and Cartier Islands, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Islands, Norfolk Island; all onshore and offshore.

The Universal Transverse Mercator coordinate system (usually simply called UTM) is a map projection system (not a projection) designed to assign coordinates to locations on the surface of the Earth. It divides the Earth into 60 zones, each 6° of longitude in width. These longitudinal zones are numbered 1 to 60 – east from longitude 180°; the polar regions south of 80°S and north of 84°N are excluded. Each zone is characterized by a central meridian; as a result, within a zone nothing is more than 3° from the central meridian and therefore locations, shapes and sizes and directions between all features are very accurate. The UTM sometimes also uses 20 latitude bands, each 8° high, numbered A to Z (with O and I not being used) – north from Antarctica. The UTM was developed in 1947 by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO).
The coordinate reference system is not known or specified.
The 49th UTM zone spanning from longitudes 108°E to 114°E. Central meridian 111°E.
The 50th UTM zone spanning from longitudes 114°E to 120°E. Central meridian 115°E.
The 51st UTM zone spanning from longitudes 120°E to 126°E. Central meridian 121°E.
The 49th UTM zone spanning from longitudes 126°E to 132°E. Central meridian 129°E.

The World Geodetic System 1984 (WGS84) is the reference frame used by the Global Positioning System (GPS). It was developed by the US Department of Defense and is maintained by the US National Geospatial Intelligence Agency (NGA). WGS84 defines an Earth-centred, Earth-fixed coordinate reference system with an origin that coincides with a determination of the centre of mass of the earth, and a geodetic datum. The datum defines meridian 0 as the International Earth Rotation and Reference System Service (IERS) Reference Meridian and the datum surface is an oblate spheroid. Officially adopted as the world geodetic datum in 1984, WGS84 is a dynamic reference frame. WGS84 has been revised several times since its conception and is at present aligned at the centimetre level to the International Terrestrial Reference Frame (ITRF), which generally ensures scientific integrity and compatibility with international standards and conventions. At the beginning of each year, the NGA updates station coordinates to account for plate tectonic motion. This means that WGS84 coordinates derived by users from GPS measurements will appear to move over time. In January 1994, GDA94 and ITRF were coincident, but since Australia is moving up to 7cm per year in a northeasterly direction, there was a 1.8 m difference between the two systems in 2020 — for applications that require uncertainty better than 5 m, GDA94 and WGS84/ITRF cannot be considered equivalent. Area of use: world.
The 49th Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 108°E and 114°E, southern hemisphere between 80°S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; Indonesia.
The 50th Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 114°E and 120°E, southern hemisphere between 80°S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; Indonesia.
The 51st Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 120°E and 126°E, southern hemisphere between 80°S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; East Timor; Indonesia.
The 49th Universal Transverse Mercator (UTM) zone. Area of use: Between 126°E and 132°E, southern hemisphere between 80°S and equator, onshore and offshore; Australia; East Timor; Indonesia.
